repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: buffer mabye not valid when callback handler invoke.

Soliton: check buffer is valid and loaded in handler.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -43,17 +43,11 @@ function M.on_inlayhint(err, result, ctx, _)
     return
   end
   local bufnr = assert(ctx.bufnr)
-  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version then
+  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version or not result or not bufstates[bufnr].enabled then

comment_data.body: bufstates[bufnr] has removed in on_detach  so check before this function invoke . reduce a function call instruction
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -43,17 +43,11 @@ function M.on_inlayhint(err, result, ctx, _)
     return
   end
   local bufnr = assert(ctx.bufnr)
-  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version then
+  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version or not result or not bufstates[bufnr].enabled then

comment_data.body: I don't fully understand the codepath, but will this be obvious to others? Is a comment needed in the handler?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -43,17 +43,11 @@ function M.on_inlayhint(err, result, ctx, _)
     return
   end
   local bufnr = assert(ctx.bufnr)
-  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version then
+  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version or not result or not bufstates[bufnr].enabled then

comment_data.body: Honestly, it works the same everywhere. this lsp handler just calls this function. your suggest is more uniform. I just wonder if there will be an extra call assembly instruction ðŸ¥²
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -43,17 +43,11 @@ function M.on_inlayhint(err, result, ctx, _)
     return
   end
   local bufnr = assert(ctx.bufnr)
-  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version then
+  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version or not result or not bufstates[bufnr].enabled then

comment_data.body: I wouldn't worry about performance here, because this condition is unusual. So readability is more important, and keeping the "skip" conditions in one place seems very helpful.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -43,17 +43,11 @@ function M.on_inlayhint(err, result, ctx, _)
     return
   end
   local bufnr = assert(ctx.bufnr)
-  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version then
+  if util.buf_versions[bufnr] ~= ctx.version or not result or not bufstates[bufnr].enabled then

comment_regular_data.body:
it's part of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/29614 

A simple idea is that handler callbacks are asynchronous. so each one needs a buffer check and result check. Can a simple factory be used to avoid some duplication of code?

```lua
local function handler_factory(fn)
    return function(err, result,ctx,config)
           return api.nvim_buf_is_loaded(ctx.bufnr) and not vim.tbl_isempty(result) and fn(err, result, ctx, config) or nil
    end
end
```

Just a thought, maybe I think too much

> Can a simple factory be used to avoid some duplication of code?

Not a factory, but each handler could call a single `_util.foo()` function that captures common checks for this scenario. 

I believe this has been discussed before? (Note: referring to private/internal utils, whereas https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/25272 is about public utils)

@MariaSolOs @mfussenegger @p00f @ofseed any objection to this PR meanwhile?

I have encountered the issue linked above before, but I couldn't reproduce it consistently at that time, and it hasn't occurred recently. It might be worth a try. LGTM, at least shouldn't cause a regression.

> any objection to this PR meanwhile?

No objection but I'd really love to see some more test coverage in this area as there have been numerous fixes now for inlay hints related to buffer state management and each time without tests - makes me worry we might play ping-pong between different edge cases.

> > Can a simple factory be used to avoid some duplication of code?
> 
> Not a factory, but each handler could call a single `_util.foo()` function that captures common checks for this scenario.
> 
> I believe this has been discussed before? (Note: referring to private/internal utils, whereas #25272 is about public utils)

@glepnir this would be a good thing to look into, and include test coverage as @mfussenegger mentioned. And if this logic is centralized, then we need fewer tests yet we gain better coverage.

title: fix(lsp): check buffer is loaded and valid in handler
